options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the commonly used French words and a lot about grammar constructions. This was a great overview necessary for learning to read French writing. Could be a great review for people coming back to French after a while
This class was essential for my progress in French comprehension and understanding of grammatical structures. I also learned a bit about French culture and the values their language expresses.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Professor Sanjabi was very organized with her course handouts. I would suggest making some of the readings we translate less dark or outdated. I understand psychology is easier for beginners to translate but theres some great French literature out there that would be fun and worthwhile to work on, especially since the translations take so long. 

I would also suggest being more organized about how we reviewed homework. I did almost all the homework and we reviewed only a small fraction of it. I struggled in this class and would have wanted to check and go over and clarify translations I spent a long time working on so that I could address mistakes and better learn.

the class moves incredibly fast, which is to be expected for a course of this nature, but the professor was incredibly willing to stop to explain concepts further. I wonder if it would be possible to have regular vocabulary tests/quizzes just to make sure people are keeping up.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Sanjabi met with me for office hours to work on my final translation. It was very helpful and I appreciated her time. I know it wasnt in person and that was tedious and frustrating for her since shes so committed to these projects but she tried to make it work online and I am grateful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I would recommend if you really want to work hard at it. If you are dedicated to learning French you will learn to read it with Professor Sanjabi. The workload is not too much busy work, leaving time to go over the textbook carefully and practice extra things that interest you or that you need to work on more. I also tried to practice with a copy of the Count of Monte Cristo, which I enjoyed far more than some of the random psychological or colonial translations we did for homework. 

That being said, I struggled with the courseI had no French experience and many of my classmates did. The class description does say its intended for people with no experience. My academic and preprofessional background is in political and military science, and I felt that the class and classmates were a bit judgemental of my lack of art history/renaissance/classics background. I was also the only undergrad in what is listed as an undergraduate course. I didnt really feel welcome in the class, but all that being said, Professor Sanjabi is dedicated to helping her students learn and improve, and I am happy with what I learned and the foundation the course gave me.

definitely, but i would caution them that they will get out of it exactly what they are willing to put in. additionally, i would recommend that they take a basic french class too. i struggled a bit and that's with a couple years of (rusty) french under my belt. i don't know if i would have survived without that.
